i'm an ai language model and not a doctor, but if your tonsil is swollen, painful, and bleeding, it could possibly be tonsillitis, which is an infection of the tonsils, or a tonsil stone, which is a buildup of debris that can get lodged in your tonsils. other possibilities can be peritonsillar abscess or other throat infections. 

please make sure you see a healthcare professional as soon as possible. if you can't get to a doctor right now because it's the weekend, and if the pain is extreme or you start to have difficulty breathing, consider going to an urgent care center or the emergency room. remember that it's always crucial to seek professional medical advice for health concerns - self-diagnosis can be inaccurate and dangerous. 

also, try to stay hydrated in the meantime and rest as much as possible. avoid any irritants, like smoking or alcohol, as these can increase the inflammation. using a humidifier to keep your throat moist may also help alleviate discomfort. 

this advice is intended to be general in nature, and specific causes may not apply to your situation. always consult with a healthcare provider for accurate information.

i'm an ai developed to assist with information, not a doctor, but i can tell you that your symptoms may indicate a possible infection such as tonsillitis. it could also be tonsil stones, which can lead to irritated and inflamed tonsils. the presence of blood could mean that there's been some damage to the area, possibly from a secondary infection or from coughing or the tonsil stone itself. infections like these typically require antibiotics. aspirin (or ibuprofen, if there's no contraindication for you) can help with the pain and inflammation prior to seeing a doctor. but if the bleeding continues, or you have additional symptoms like high fever or difficulty breathing, it may indicate a more serious situation and you should seek medical help urgently. remember, this advice is intended to be general in nature, you need to contact a healthcare professional who can consider your full medical history.

i'm an ai language model and while i can't look at images or diagnose conditions, the symptoms you describe like your tonsil becoming painful, appearing swollen, looking yellowish, and secreting blood, could suggest an infection like tonsillitis or a tonsillar abscess. 

tonsillitis is an inflammation of the tonsils which can be caused by bacteria or viruses. symptoms can include sore throat, red swollen tonsils, pain when swallowing, fever, headaches and yellow or white patches appearing on the tonsils. 

a peritonsillar abscess is a more serious condition where an abscess forms around the tonsils due to a bacterial infection. aside from the obvious swelling, you might have severe throat pain (usually one side), difficulty swallowing, fever, chills, or earaches. 

it's also possible for tonsil stones to cause tonsil bleeding. however, these usually don't cause much pain or any inflammation/swelling. it's important to note that the presence of blood is a sign that you should seek emergency medical care. 

it's best you seek medical attention as soon as possible. in the meantime, over-the-counter pain medication can help manage the pain and you should keep yourself hydrated, rest, and avoid any irritation to your throat (from smoking, etc).

i'm an ai designed to give advice based on specific scenarios but i'm unable to actually look at the image you linked. however, based on the symptoms you're describing, it sounds like you could have tonsillitis. this is an infection or inflammation of the tonsils. the most common cause is viral, but it can also be bacterial. the condition is usually self-limiting, meaning it will often go away on its own, but in some cases you might need antibiotics—particularly if it turns out to be a bacterial infection.

symptoms of tonsillitis include: a sore throat; difficulty swallowing; hoarse or no voice; a high temperature of 38c or above; coughing; headache; feeling sick; earache; feeling tired. sometimes the symptoms can be severe and you may also see white or yellow spots on the tonsils.

while waiting to see your doctor, some things that can help ease the symptoms include: getting plenty of rest; drinking cool fluids to soothe the throat; taking over-the-counter pain relievers to reduce pain and control your fever.

please note that this advice is based on general medical knowledge and for your specific case, you should still reach out to a healthcare professional for advice. it's good to inform you that in severe cases or cases where tonsillitis is recurrent, a tonsillectomy or surgery to remove the tonsils may be necessary. so, whenever possible, try and see a healthcare professional.
